newsitem.title: FRANCE: French court rejects far-right bid to shut theatre.
newsitem.headline: French court rejects far-right bid to shut theatre.

text.p: A French court rejected on Thursday a demand by a far-right National Front mayor for the closure of a theatre and cultural complex in the southern port city of Toulon.

Several thousand artists and supporters had marched through Toulon in February to combat the municipality's drive to sack the Chateauvallon theatre's left-wing director Gerard Paquet and close his centre.

"(The ruling) is a great victory. The next step is to reinstate Paquet in his post," Paquet's lawyer Jean Guy Levy told reporters. The public prosecutor had argued that there was insufficient ground to close the complex.
Chateauvallon became a symbol of opposition to the Front when city subsidies to the centre were stopped following the party's victory in municipal elections in 1995.
Paquet, after a series of clashes, was sacked in February for failure to get mayor Jean-Marie Le Chevallier's approval for printing the programme for 1997.
Lawyer Didier Gestat de Garambe, an aide to Le Chevallier, said that, if Paquet had not been dismissed, the centre would have been ordered shut down by the court.
The arts establishment has clashed repeatedly with the anti-immigration National Front in the party's four southern municipal bastions, denouncing censorship in libraries and at cultural events.
Culture Minister Philippe Douste-Blazy and writers protested in Toulon late last year against Le Chevallier's ban on a tribute to Jewish writer Marek Halter.
